[Description]: Whether the technique facilitates understanding- communicating or describing a process
Whether the technique facilitates the analyzing (and improving) of a process
Whether the technique facilitates the execution of a process- and/or is generally used with the aim of creating executable models
Whether the technique facilitates the and/or is generally used for the managing and monitoring of a process
What process elements / Functional dependencies between process elements (activities- subprocesses- etcetera)
When and how activities are performed
Data (entities) produced or manipulated by a process- and their relationships. In other words- the structure of informational entities
Where and by whom activities are performed- both functionally and physically.
Language is designed to be used for modeling the widest variety of application domains
The language notation is textual
The language notation is graphical
Textual but with predefined tabular structure (often for natural language description of processes).
Graphical highly formal semtantics based on formal logic. Modeling requires knowledge about math and/or logic.
Whether the language allows for for imperative modeling: Procedural. Processes with a clear start and clear end (state). E.g. workflows.

Whether the language allows for declarative modeling: Knowledge intensive- no clear start to end and many variatons possible (variations not all known in advance). For declarative approaches you define the boundaries and anything within the boundaries is possible.
Whether the language allows for the modeling of an order in which tasks are to be executed. In other words- whether the language includes a concept of time
Whether the messages and their flow can be modeled
Whether the language explicitly allows for the modeling of the flow of data
Whether the language contains the OR construct
Whether the language contains the XOR construct
Whether the language contains the AND construct- e.g. Flowchart does not have this
Whether the language allows for the modeling process input. Typically- these are resources referenced and/or consumed by activities/tasks/functions
Whether the language allows for the modeling of deliverables or output- e.g. the creation of a document
Whether the language allows for the explicit modeling of external entities that perform a certain process element

Whether the language allows for the explicit modeling of actors- roles and organizational units that perform a certain process element. An entity is a definable thing- such as a person object concept or event- that can have data stored about it
Whether there is a construct to depict duration- represent a time span- the passage of time- or a specific point in time (e.g. a day of the week)
Whether there is a construct to depict the time period within activities or tasks have to be carried out
Whether language allows for the modeling of business rules
Whether language allows for the explicit modeling of business goals (note: a final state is not considered a process goal for this feature)

Whether language allows for textual annotation in addition the graphical representation of a process. Textual annotation can be used to provide additional details about a process element- that otherwise could not be depicted.
Whether the language has a "task" or "activity" construct
Whether the language has an "event" construct. An event is an occurance that takes place at a specific point in time- and that is capable of inducing some behaviour (e.g. acitivity or process)
Whether the language has a formal specification for mapping to an Executable Business Process (Modeling) Language
Whether the language has a standard file format specified
Petri Net Markup Language- XML-based interchange format for Petri Net files
Defines what elements and attributes may appear in XML document
File format used to store model design information in standard XML format
YAWL-XML- file format specifically used for yawl files
EPC Markup Language- neutral interchange format that facilitates interchange of EPC business process models
Extensible Markup Language: a set of codes or tags that describes the text in a digital document. More broad than XSD and XMI
Whether there are any Execution Engines available that support the (automatic) simulation of the models of a given language
Whether the language allows for simulation (enaction of the model)
Whether the language allows for qualitative analysis- e.g. The detecting of deadlocks- races- etcetera
Whether the language allows for true-parallelism- explicitly representing steps that can be performed by different workers.
Whether the output model of the language is to be used or interpreted by systems
Whether the language allows for decomposition / process nesting
Whether the language allows for high-level modeling (top-down approach)
Whether the language allows for low-level modeling (bottom-up approach) with detailed descriptions of atomic activities
Whether the modeling language allows for modeling of state-based models
Whether the language allows for the modeling of activity/task-based models
Whether the language is generally perceived as being suitable/understandable for/by novice modelers
Whether the language is generally perceived as being suitable/understandable for/by or tailored to experts or well-experienced modelers

The degree of the number of unique graphical symbols the language has (Note: The assumption is made that a higher amount results in lower understandability- but higher expressiveness). Featured not applicable (=0) to textual process modeling languages.
Whether the language uses color as additional differentiating factor for the notation of elements
The degree of formality: the extend to which a language has well defined semantics and rules to be followed
Extent to which symbols are clearly distinguishable- as perceived in literature
Self describing: extent to which meaning of symbol can be inferred from its appearance- as perceived in literature
Whether there is an organization behind the language- actively responsible for version management and development of the language- e.g. OMG
Whether the technique is conform to an ISO standard
Whether new and improved versions have been released over time
The level of theoretical support for the business process modeling technique (i.e. whether its has its foundations in the academic domain)
Availability of a comprehensive and well-documented manual or language specification

Whether the technique has an active community. An active community is defined as a group of people (modelers) gathered in a place to achieve a common goal (in this case being an online forum or an active research community)
Degree of expert availability (*may vary over time)
The degree of training material availability
Whether there are instructional youtube videos available about the technique (Language: EN)
Whether there are courses available at recognized organizations- e.g. UvA or UU- about the technique
Whether there are blogs / articles available about the technique
The degree of popularity of the given technique (3 = very popular)
The degree of tool availability for both free and paid tools combined
Whether there are any free tools available that support the modeling using a certain technique
Whether there are any open source tools available that support the modeling using a certain technique
